title: 111_hr2745
content: The Act titled "TARP Repayment and Termination Act of 2009" introduces additional repayment procedures to the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008. The TARP Repayment and Termination Act of 2009 allows financial institutions to repay assistance received under the act if they will be well capitalized after repayment and have met all payment obligations to the Secretary. Bank holding companies assessed under SCAP also have the right to repay assistance. SCAP allows companies to repay assistance if they can maintain their role as a lending intermediary, meet capital requirements, support subsidiary banks, and fulfill funding obligations. The financial institution must be able to meet funding requirements and reduce reliance on Government capital and TLGP. Repayment of assistance allows repurchase of preferred shares at the same price purchased by the Secretary. The financial institution must repay assistance received under this title, which will reduce the authorization to purchase authority. The Secretary must accept the repayment within 15 days or notify the institution if repayment is not currently feasible. The institution must repay assistance received under this title, reducing the authorization to purchase authority. The Secretary must accept repayment within 15 days or notify if repayment is not feasible. Definitions for terms like 'appropriate Federal banking agency', 'bank holding company', and 'insured depository institution' are provided. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms like 'SCAP', 'TLGP', and 'well capitalized' in relation to depository institutions. The curr_chunk amends warrant liquidation requirements and repeals extension authority under the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008. The curr_chunk introduces additional repayment procedures.
